Situation1: They notice a small discrepancy in the register but it doesn’t affect the total sales for the day.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Story: I stand behind the register, counting bills, when I notice a small discrepancy—just a few dollars off, nothing that will affect the day’s totals. Store policy is clear: every cent must be accounted for, no matter how minor. My manager expects me to report even the smallest error, but I know it will mean paperwork, questions, and possibly suspicion cast on my honesty or competence. As I weigh my options, my phone buzzes in my pocket. It’s an email from a young couple, asking if I can officiate their wedding next year. As a rabbi, I’m honored by their trust, and I know how important it is to respond promptly and warmly, to make them feel valued and supported at this pivotal moment in their lives. But the store is busy, and my break is almost over. I feel the pressure of both roles—one demanding strict adherence to rules, the other calling for compassion and presence. My heart pounds as I realize I can’t give both the attention they deserve at this moment.
